title: After the Dramatic Rescues , the Hidden Toll of Disasters is Felt by Millions
message:
Earthquakes, powerful storms, tsunamis and other disasters have powerful immediate impacts, but they also do long-term damage that often gets overlooked.
The region is home to more than 80% of about 206 million people affected by disasters globally each year.
But an often-neglected aspect is the indirect human and economic toll that is still felt years, even decades, after the disaster.
Disaster impacts can also transmit far beyond the disaster epicenter through temporary migration or permanent resettlement.
Asia and the Pacific must continue to respond to disasters with immediate life-saving aid and reconstruction of the directly affected areas.

title: Tropical Storm Hone threatens Hawaii with fire and floods
message:

title: What is a tsunami ? Can they happen along the East & Gulf Coasts ?
message:
The tsunami energy was propagated by a submarine landslide and although the maximum tsunami was recorded near the earthquake epicenter in Newfoundland, there were some tsunami waves recorded as far south as in South Carolina.
East and Gulf Coast tsunamis are low frequency.
There is a subduction zone in the Caribbean Sea and the tsunamis recorded in areas along the Gulf Coast states have been less than one meter or 3.28 feet.
Meteotsunamis are progressive waves limited to the tsunami frequency band of wave periods (between two minutes and two hours).
Storm surge is the abnormal rise in sea level caused by a storm, often a tropical system, apart from the predicted astronomical tide.

title: What is a tsunami ? Can they happen along the East Coast ?
message:
For us on the East Coast, a tsunami will be more likely caused by a submarine landslide like the one that occurred in 1929 after a Magnitude 7.2 quake stroke near Newfoundland, Canada.
The tsunami energy was propagated by a submarine landslide and although the maximum tsunami was recorded near the earthquake epicenter in Newfoundland, there were some tsunami waves recorded as far south as in South Carolina.
East and Gulf Coast tsunamis are low frequency.
They don’t just occur along the coast, but they can happen in lakes, bays, or inlets.
Meteotsunamis are progressive waves limited to the tsunami frequency band of wave periods (between two minutes and two hours).

title: Denman earthquake , NSW : Earthquake rocks NSW town
message:

title: Manatee County residents claiming stormwater bacteria is killing their animals
message:
MANATEE COUNTY, Fla. (WWSB) - Following Hurricane Debby, high storm water levels have forced the relocation of horses, cattle, pets, and more.
Several Manatee County residents have said their cows have died, pets have become sick, and other livestock have either fallen ill or died as well.
“I feel terrible,” said Wes Matejka, a Myakka man who saw no flooding at all.
“We got extremely lucky, we happened to purchase the highest elevation property in the county,” he added.
Carol Felts, a longtime livestock owner in Manatee County and recent winner of a Manatee County election, said the infection of cuts as well as ingestion of chemicals can be horribly detrimental to these animals.

title: Forest Service urges Mississippians to prevent wildfires
message:
(WJTV) – The U.S. Forest Service is urging visitors to exercise caution while visiting national forests this weekend because most of Mississippi is abnormally dry or in a moderate to severe drought.
“Please keep wildfire prevention in mind when visiting a national forest,” said Jay Boykin, Forest Service Fire Duty Officer.
If campfires or grills are allowed, keep the fire small, never leave them unattended and put it out completely before leaving.
If campfires are allowed, clear vegetation away from your campfire area and use a preexisting campfire ring when possible.
Make sure your campfire is cold to the touch before leaving it.

title: Tropical Storm Hone forms in the central Pacific Ocean , Gilma still a Category 3 hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Hone forms in the central Pacific Ocean, Gilma still a Category 3 hurricaneHONOLULU (AP) — Tropical Storm Hone formed in the central Pacific Ocean on Thursday on a forecast path that may cross near Hawaii's Big Island, while major Hurricane Gilma remained a Category 3 storm at sea.
Hone had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph) and was centered about 1,090 miles (1,760 kilometers) east-southeast of Honolulu, the Central Pacific Hurricane Center said in an 11 a.m. advisory.
Meanwhile, Hurricane Gilma remained a major hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 125 mph (205 kph).
Gilma was trailing behind Hone, located about 1,980 miles (3,185 kilometers) east of Hilo and moving west-northwest at 7 mph (11 kph).
The system strengthened to tropical storm status on Sunday and has grown more powerful since then.

title: Mississippi sees increase of wildfires due to dry conditions
message:
(WJTV) – Officials with the Mississippi Forestry Commission (MFC) said parts of Mississippi are experiencing an abnormally dry period.
State Forester Russell Bozeman said this is the time of year the state begins to see a fall drought pattern.
So, we’ve seen a lot of forest health issues since the drought last year.
So all this year, we’ve dealt with with beetle problems, caterpillar problems, fungus problems, all kinds of forest health issues that we’ve been seeing out in the forest.
So if we end up into an extended drought period, then we could continue to see tree and tree health issues,” he explained.

message:
Officials raise serious concerns with new report on this year's devastating wildfire season in Oregon: 'It's really important'The 2024 wildfire season has already been the most destructive one on record for the state of Oregon, OregonLive reported.
Seventy-one large fires have burned more than 1.4 million acres since the 2024 wildfire season began (which, according to the Western Fire Chiefs Association, happens in mid-May).
Historically, the state has seen the most wildfires in September, which means that the final numbers could eclipse previous state records.
Oregon state officials stressed that people should be extra careful about fire safety this time of year and avoid accidentally starting fires.
Although the conditions that have led the fires to spread are due to climate change, more than 70% of fires are started by people, according to the Oregon Wildfire Response & Recovery website.

title: Met Office issues Storm Lilian warning as flooding could hit united kingdom in just HOURS
message:
Flooding as a result of Storm Lilian could hit within hours, forecasts have warned.
The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for rain in the South East as Lilian continues to batter the UK.
The warning lasts until 1pm tomorrow, bringing a dismal start to the Bank Holiday weekend for millions.
The Met Office warned of "spells of rain, heavy at times" which were "likely to cause some travel disruption and perhaps flooding in a few places".
It comes after a chaotic 24 hours in which parts of the UK were hit hard by strong winds brought about by the storm.

title: A robot attempt to get a sample of the melted fuel at Japan damaged nuclear reactor is suspended
message:
A robot's attempt to get a sample of the melted fuel at Japan's damaged nuclear reactor is suspendedThis photo provided by the Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings shows what they call a "Telesco-style" extendable pipe robot on July 10, 2024.
(TEPCO via AP)TOKYO (AP) — An attempt to use an extendable robot to remove a fragment of melted fuel from a wrecked reactor at Japan’s tsunami-hit Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant was suspended Thursday due to a technical issue.
The pipes were to be used to push the robot inside and pull it back out when it finished.
Better understanding of the melted fuel debris is key to decommissioning the three wrecked reactors and the entire plant.
No specific plans for the full removal of the melted fuel debris or its storage have been decided.

title: Katrina Wake - up Call : The Urgency of Climate Action Now - The Sacramento Observer
message:
But as extreme weather events continue to intensify, driven by climate change, the stakes couldn’t be higher.
And while climate change threatens everyone, its effects are not felt equally.
The success of the IRA has shown us that we can make meaningful progress on climate change, but we cannot afford to slow down.
We must continue to advocate for policies that are equitable, just, and grounded in the needs of the communities most impacted by climate change.
It’s about whether we have the courage to build a more resilient, equitable, and sustainable future for all.

title: Reports Highlight Compounding Impacts , Costs of Extreme Weather Events
message:
Earlier this month, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted that the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season could rank “among the busiest on record,” as climate change continues to cause more extreme weather events.
With the number of such events caused by warming ocean temperatures and other climate change set to grow, costs also wiil rise—in some cases exponentially.
Most existing building codes now focus on preventing loss of life, not restoring functionality, says Maria Lehman, past president of ASCE and vice chair of the National Infrastructure Advisory Council.
Efforts are underway to quantify true costs in a more holistic way, by the federal standards agency, the World Bank and others.
Lehman points to a recent GHD study that found widespread—although uneven—support across generations in several countries to address climate change and reduce carbon emissions.

title: Flooding : Is it time to stop living in basements ?
message:
And that doesn’t take into account the largely overlooked human and social consequences on our communities of flooding.
From cellars designed to store coal, to basements converted into living environmentsIn the past, cellars were dark, damp, utilitarian spaces designed to store coal and other provisions.
The use of basements as living spaces has become a particularly popular practice in Québec, but also elsewhere in northeast North America.
Reducing the damage caused by flooding requires a multidimensional approach, combining short-term prevention measures with in-depth action.
By taking action, we will be helping to reduce inequalities and ensure a better living environment for all.

title: The Gulf of Mexico is blazing hot , but hurricane season is ominously quiet
message:
The Gulf of Mexico is blazing hot, but hurricane season is ominously quietStorm surge pushes water past wind swept palm trees along the Gulf of Mexico, in Horseshoe Beach, Fla., on Aug. 5.
The Gulf of Mexico is blazing hot, but hurricane season — temporarily, at least — has hit a lull, a surprise to researchers who see plenty of ingredients brewing in the Atlantic but no storms on the radar.
Hurricane season begins June 1 and ends Nov. 30.
Hurricane scientists predicted a record hurricane season this year, and it got off to a record-setting start when Hurricane Beryl became the first Category 4 storm to form in the Atlantic Ocean in June.
The unofficial peak of hurricane season is Sept. 10.

title: Which Mississippi counties are under a burn ban in 2024 ?
message:
Which Mississippi counties are under a burn ban in 2024?
(WJTV) – As dry conditions persist in Mississippi this year, some counties have been placed under burn bans.
According to the Mississippi Forestry Commission (MFC), the following counties were placed under burn bans:Adams County – Aug. 5 to Sept. 5, 2024Franklin County – Aug. 23 to Sept. 23, 2024Noxubee County – Aug. 23 to Sept. 23, 2024Winston County – Aug. 22 to Sept. 5, 2024Burn bans are restrictions on outdoor burning during drought or wildfire conditions.

title: Storm Lilian live updates : Leeds Festival closes two stages as Storm Lilian brings strong wind to united kingdom
message:
'Worst day ever', says Leeds Festival goer"It's honestly really bad here," says a Leeds Festival attendee whose tent has been destroyed by Storm Lillian.
"The fabric ripped open and leaked the whole tent with the rain," says Carrie Gill, 19, a university student who says she was told to leave the area by festival organisers.
"All our stuff is in our mates' tent, phones on 30%, all the stores have blown over, the urinal walls are gone and lads are just pissing against fences, people's tents are in the sky," she says.
Gill has spent £60 on a replacement tent, but it's still too windy to put it up so she's waiting in a nearby McDonald's.
"As you can imagine being a student, it's quite an expensive festival to be going to and to be let down like this," she says, "it's the worst day ever."

message:

(NOAA via AP)MEXICO CITY (AP) – Tropical Storm Hone has formed in the central Pacific Ocean, forecasters said, on a path that may cross near Hawaii’s Big Island.
Meanwhile, Hurricane Gilma remained a major hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 125 mph (205 kph).

title: Tropical Storm Hone forms in the central Pacific Ocean , Gilma still a Category 3 hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Hone formed in the central Pacific Ocean on Thursday on a forecast path that may cross near Hawaiʻi Island, while major Hurricane Gilma remained a Category 3 storm at sea.
Hone had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph and was centered about 1,090 miles east-southeast of Honolulu, the Central Pacific Hurricane Center said in an 11 a.m. advisory.
Meanwhile, Hurricane Gilma remained a major hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 125 mph.
Gilma was trailing behind Hone, located about 1,980 miles east of Hilo and moving west-northwest at 7 mph.
Hurricane-force winds extended outward up to 35 miles from the center of Gilma and tropical-storm-force winds extended outward up to 115 miles, the National Hurricane Center in Miami said.

title: Parishes respond with prayer , outreach amid historic Northeast floods
message:
Two women in the town of Oxford drowned as rescuers tried to save them.
A volunteer staffer at St. Thomas the Apostle Parish in Oxford told OSV News that while the church buildings were intact, "a lot of people here" in the parish "did get hit" by the flooding.
The priest told OSV News the parish's two churches "are on high ground" and did not sustain any damage.
On its Facebook page, St. Thomas the Apostle invited those affected to contact the parish for help.
Lord, please be with everyone waiting to be rescued, keep them safe, and bring help to them soon," read the prayer.

title: Tropical Storm Hone forms in the central Pacific Ocean , Gilma still a Category 3 hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Hone formed in the central Pacific Ocean on Thursday on a forecast path that may cross near Hawaii's Big Island, while major Hurricane Gilma remained a Category 3 storm at sea.
Hone had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph) and was centered about 1,090 miles (1,760 kilometers) east-southeast of Honolulu, the Central Pacific Hurricane Center said in an 11 a.m. advisory.
Meanwhile, Hurricane Gilma remained a major hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 125 mph (205 kph).
Gilma was trailing behind Hone, located about 1,980 miles (3,185 kilometers) east of Hilo and moving west-northwest at 7 mph (11 kph).
Hurricane-force winds extended outward up to 35 miles (56 kilometers) from the center of Gilma and tropical-storm-force winds extended outward up to 115 miles (185 kilometers), the National Hurricane Center in Miami said.

title: Tornado - Like Waterspouts Are  More Likely  as the Mediterranean Warms
message:
The type of weather phenomenon that may have led billionaire Mike Lynch’s yacht to sink in the Mediterranean this week is now more likely to happen as global warming has raised sea temperatures, according to climate experts.
Tornado-like events are not uncommon in Italian waters during the late summer, as sea temperatures are at their warmest levels, but this year has been exceptionally hot.
The Mediterranean broke the record for its highest ever daily mean sea surface temperature with 28.47C (83.2 F) on Aug. 15.
A University of Barcelona study of areas around the Balearic Islands found waterspouts are more likely in warmer waters.
Yet extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and intense across the region as global temperatures continue to increase.

title: Montreal - area mayors say Quebec government has not delivered on promised flood relief | iNFOnews
message:
The Communauté métropolitaine de Montréal (CMM), which represents 82 municipalities, says there has been no meaningful change to the program if sewer backups located far from waterways are not included.
People living on certain streets have been told they're eligible for financial aid, he said, while residents of other streets have been told they're out of luck.
But the site also says homeowners are only eligible for assistance for sewer backups "if a nearby waterway overflowed."
Alain Mailhot, a professor of urban hydrology at Quebec's national scientific research institute, said it doesn't make sense to compensate people for sewer backups only if they live close to a river.
In a press release, the group requested that sewer backups caused by "urban runoff" during episodes of heavy rain be eligible for government aid.

title: County officials identify what behind chronic flooding in Security - Widefield
message:
EL PASO COUNTY, Colo. (KRDO) - After years of flooding in Security-Widefield, El Paso County Officials say they're working on a study to determine the root of the issue in infrastructure to prevent further flooding.
Jack Ladley, the Director of Public Works for El Paso County, says that the issue stems from 50 to 100-year-old infrastructure in the southeast part of El Paso County.

title: B . C . wildfires trending into the  held  and mop - up stages - The Chilliwack Progress
message:
The BC Wildfire Service says the Shetland Creek wildfire, which had triggered evacuation orders and alerts in the southern Interior since it was first detected on July 12, is now classified as “being held” at about 280 square kilometres in size.
The service says many fires are in the “mop-up” stage, when crews move in to douse the edges of a blaze with water in order to fully contain it.
Still, it says recent rainfall has not been enough to alleviate severe drought across many areas of the province, and it’s still an active wildfire season.
Just under 100 of B.C.’s active blazes are classified as burning out of control.
Campfires continue to be prohibited with the exception of the Prince George Fire Centre, the Haida Gwaii Forest District and the northwestern corner of B.C.

title: Extreme climate change : NOAA reports new terminology to address
message:
Creating a new language for climate change: NOAA releases a report describing a new term, "super-marine heatwaves," which has never been used before.
Scientists now have a new term, “super-marine heatwaves,” which has never been used before to address rising sea surface temperatures.
With decades of data, NOAA released a chart highlighting the changes in sea surface temperature in waters worldwide.
The sea surface temperatures are collected from the uppermost layer of seawater, which typically means the top few meters, NOAA explains.

Flash flooding and the risk for a few strong to severe storms for portions of Utah as we head into the weekend.

title: A robot attempt to get a sample of the melted fuel at Japan damaged nuclear reactor is suspended
message:
An attempt to use an extendable robot to remove a fragment of melted fuel from a wrecked reactor at Japan’s tsunami-hit Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant was suspended Thursday due to a technical issue.
The pipes were to be used to push the robot inside and pull it back out when it finished.
The small sample will provide key data to develop future decommissioning methods and necessary technology and robots, experts say.
CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APPBetter understanding of the melted fuel debris is key to decommissioning the three wrecked reactors and the entire plant.
No specific plans for the full removal of the melted fuel debris or its storage have been decided.

title: Clues sought in shooting that injured Denmark store owner
message:
DENMARK, S.C. (WRDW/WAGT) - Authorities are asking the public for help as they investigate a shooting earlier this month at a convenience store in Denmark.
The shooting happened after 8 p.m. on Aug. 6 at the Denmark Grocery, 59 Magnolia Ave.
The store owner was shot, taken to a hospital and treated for injuries.
The South Carolina Law Enforcement Division is assisting Denmark police with the investigation, and released surveillance images from the store.
The shooting came amid an outbreak of violent crime that’s claimed more than 170 lives in a little over two years across the CSRA .

message:

With mostly sunny skies, we’ll reach for the mid and upper 80s with our mountains trying for the low 80s.
Tuesday starts with sun & clouds with temps warming up steadily into the mid and upper 80s by the afternoon.
Thursday partly sunny skies gives us a few hours of sunshine helping temps warm up into the mid and upper 80s.

title: Lockheed Martin Marks 70 Years of C - 130 Aircraft in Flight
message:
Inside the cavernous Lockheed Martin aircraft manufacturing plant at Dobbins Air Reserve Base, employees Thursday celebrated nearly 70 years of flight for the C-130 tactical airlifter -- built in Marietta as the longest-running military aircraft production line in history.
During an all-employee event Thursday for the anniversary, Lockheed Martin also honored four employees who have worked there for at least 60 years.
The U.S. Air Force commissioned what was then Lockheed Aircraft Corp. to build a military cargo transport that could airlift combat troops and deliver them to small airfields.
The future for HerculesIt's yet to be seen what the ultimate life span of C-130 production will be.
"I would have told you in 2010 that we wouldn't be producing C-130Js in 2020," said Lockheed Martin Aeronautics President Greg Ulmer.

title: National Hurricane Center tracking 4 tropical waves as we near the peak of storm season
message:
National Hurricane Center tracking 4 tropical waves as we near the peak of storm seasonFor the North Atlantic, Caribbean Sea and the Gulf of Mexico, tropical cyclone formation is not expected during the next seven days.
The Atlantic hurricane season is from June 1 to Nov. 30 every year, with the most active part of the season between August and October.
What are the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season names?
According to the National Hurricane Center in Miami, these are the list of names for the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season:AlbertoBerylChrisDebbyErnestoFrancineGordonHeleneIsaacJoyceKirkLeslieMiltonNadineOscarPattyRafaelSaraTonyValerieWilliamWhat happens if we run out of hurricane names?
These are the supplemental hurricane names for the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season:AdriaBraylenCaridadDeshawnEmeryFosterGemmaHeathIslaJacobusKenzieLucioMakaylaNolanOrlandaPaxRoninSophieTayshaunVivianaWillContributing: Cheryl McCloud, USA TODAY Network-FloridaThis article originally appeared on Florida Today: Hurricane season: 4 tropical waves in Atlantic, 2 in Caribbean Sea

title: Another sales - tax holiday kicks off Saturday across Florida
message:
The state also held a similar tax holiday around the June 1 start of the six-month hurricane season.
Meteorological experts have forecast an above-average hurricane season this year, which could mean more than 20 named storms before the end of November.
Florida Emergency Management Director Kevin Guthrie this week advised people not to be fooled by the current calm in the Atlantic and to use the tax holiday that starts Saturday to "go out and restock or stock for disaster items."
"We're entering the peak weeks of hurricane season," Guthrie said Wednesday while in Sarasota.
The tax holiday starting Saturday and the similar period around the start of hurricane season are projected to trim $80.2 million from state and local tax revenues.

title: NEOC to convene following Ernesto - Premier Wheatley | Virgin Islands News Online
message:
You are here: Virgin Islands News Online News » NEOC to convene following Ernesto- Premier WheatleyThe National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) will convene today, Wednesday, August 14, 2024, to receive reports from various agencies following the effects of Hurricane Ernesto.
Photo: Government of the Virgin IslandsROAD TOWN, Tortola, VI- The National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) will convene today, Wednesday, August 14, 2024, to receive reports from various agencies following the effects of Hurricane Ernesto.
Premier and Minister for Finance Honourable Dr. Natalio D. Wheatley in a statement released today said, “Ernesto has left downed trees and power lines and scattered debris into the roads of the Territory.
At the moment, crews from Public Works, the BVIEC, and telecommunication providers are working to clear roads and restore services."
Premier Wheatley also urged residents to remain safe at home until the all-clear is issued.

title: Japan postpones trial removal of nuclear debris from Fukushima reactor
message:
TOKYO: The operator of Japan's stricken Fukushima nuclear power plant said this week's trial removal of radioactive debris from a battered reactor has been postponed due to a technical issue.
Tokyo Electric Power Company (Tepco) was aiming to remove a tiny sample of the estimated 880 tons of radioactive debris believed to sit inside reactors at the tsunami-hit nuclear plant.
The trial removal will not resume on Friday as the operator has to "investigate the cause of the trouble," another spokesman Tatsuya Matoba told AFP on Friday.
Three of Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant's six reactors were operating when a tsunami hit on Mar 11, 2011, knocking down cooling systems and sending them into meltdown in what became the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl.
In three units of the Fukushima plant, fuel and other material melted and then solidified into highly radioactive "fuel debris".

title: A third of California is  abnormally dry , drought monitor says . Where are conditions worst ?
message:
About 6.9% of California was under moderate drought conditions as of Thursday and 0.1% was under severe drought conditions, the map indicated.
About 33.4% of California is under “abnormally dry conditions” as of Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor.
About 6.9% of the state is under “moderate drought” conditions and 0.1% is under “severe drought” conditions.
Meanwhile, 33.4% of California was battling abnormally dry conditions as of Thursday, the Drought Monitor said.
As of Thursday morning, an estimated 72,714 California residents were living in drought conditions, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor.

title: Mason County wildfire burns 3 , 000 acres , 10 % contained
message:
Mason County wildfire ignited by lightning, forest service says; 4,000 acres burned and 30% containedMASON COUNTY, Texas (KXAN) — The Mason Volunteer Fire Department and several other fire departments across the Hill Country are working to put out a wildfire in Mason County Friday morning.
The Texas A&M Forest Service said the fire is currently an estimated 3,000 acres and 10% contained.
(Courtesy: Ashley Airheart Duarte)View from Ranch Road 1900 of the “North Art Complex” wildfire in Mason County Aug. 23, 2024.

The Texas A&M Forest Service said on Friday morning the fire has burned over 3,000 acres and has been 10% contained.

message:
St. Charles, IL, Aug. 22, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Due to changing climate patterns, severe flooding, thunderstorms, and extreme heat have become common in St. Charles in recent years.
St. Charles Roofing, a premier roofing contractor technology platform, advocates for timely repairs for storm-damaged roofs.

title: Stony Brook University students move on campus after three - day storm delay
message:
Hundreds of Stony Brook University students moved into their dorms Thursday following a three-day delay after a torrential downpour early Monday flooded two residence halls, creating havoc on campus along with millions of dollars in damage in the region.
Compared to the pandemic, the three-day delay at Stony Brook was nothing, she said.
"It’s really impressive how quickly Stony Brook got their act together,” Jami said.
"Just another kid.”Stony Brook officials said Thursday they still did not know the number of students displaced by the flooding.
Cleanup continues at the Ammann Hall dormitory on the Stony Brook University campus on Thursday.

title: Mini heat wave on tap for Lincoln this weekend
message:
After an extended period of lower-than-normal temperatures, Lincoln is in for a late-summer mini heat wave this weekend.
The Weather Service said the heat index could reach as high as 105-110 degrees on both Saturday and Sunday.
Since Aug. 5, Lincoln has seen a below-normal high temperature on 14 of 17 days, including seven days in the 70s.
Drought has also been expanding statewide, with 19% of Nebraska now in at least a moderate drought, including nearly 6% in severe drought.
There was no severe drought at all in the state as recently as mid-July, while the amount of moderate drought bottomed out at around 1% in mid-June.

title: Montreal - area mayors say Quebec government has not delivered on promised flood relief – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
The government program had only compensated homeowners for water damage caused by overland flooding.
The Communauté métropolitaine de Montréal (CMM), which represents 82 municipalities, says there has been no meaningful change to the program if sewer backups located far from waterways are not included.
People living on certain streets have been told they’re eligible for financial aid, he said, while residents of other streets have been told they’re out of luck.
)”Alain Mailhot, a professor of urban hydrology at Quebec’s national scientific research institute, said it doesn’t make sense to compensate people for sewer backups only if they live close to a river.
In a press release, the group requested that sewer backups caused by “urban runoff” during episodes of heavy rain be eligible for government aid.

title: Leeds Festival campers warned to secure their tents as Storm Lilian sweeps in
message:
“So there could be potentially some impacts from those strong winds, of 50 to 60mph in the area so it’s worth making sure your tents are secured.
⚠️ Storm Lilian has been named by the Met Office.
The warning for strong winds covers parts of north Wales on Friday.
Storms are named when they have the potential to cause disruption or damage which could result in an amber or red warning, the Met Office said.
This is primarily based on impacts from strong winds but other weather types will also be considered, including rain if flood warnings are advised by national agencies, or snow.

title: Earthquake jolts Sankhuwasabha
message:
KATHMANDU, Aug 23: An earthquake jolted Sankhuwasabha district.
According to the National Earthquake Monitoring and Research Center (NEMRC), an earthquake of 3.9 magnitude jolted Sankuwasahba at 3:07 PM on Friday, with its epicenter around Gadi Danda Bazar.
The Sankhuwasabha administration said that it is uncertain how much damage was caused by the earthquake and they are in the process of gathering further details.

title: Storm Lilian : Leeds Festival campers warned to secure tents as weather system set to bring chaos
message:
Storm Lilian, which has also caused travel disruption and power cuts, blew away tents at Leeds Festival, where campers filmed heavy rain lashed across the siteTents have been blown away at Leeds Festival amid the fierce gales caused by Storm Lilian.
Further gusts of up to 80mph are still expected, with travel disruption, flooding, power cuts and dangerous conditions near coastal areas all likely.
The forecaster has issued two yellow weather warnings for rain in south-west Scotland and the Aberdeenshire coast from 9pm on Thursday to 9am on Friday.
A yellow wind warning has also come into force covering northern England and north Wales until 11am on Friday, with the storm widely expected to bring gusts of 50-60mph in the region.
RAC Breakdown spokeswoman Alice Simpson said the adverse weather and large volume of expected trips represented “a perfect storm” for drivers.

title: Flights axed as Storm Lilian brings travel disruption to bank holiday weekend
message:
The cancellations include international flights to Italy, Switzerland and the US as well as domestic journeys to Scotland and Northern Ireland.
The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for rain spanning much of South East England from 6am to 1pm on Saturday.
A separate wind warning was also in place across northern England and north Wales until 11am on Friday, with the storm widely expected to bring gusts of 50-60mph in the region.
Lilian is the 12th named storm of the season – the furthest the Met Office has got through the list since it was introduced – and the first since April.
Storms are named when they have the potential to cause disruption or damage which could result in an amber or red warning, the Met Office said.
